Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Dexmedetomidine and Ketorolac for Postoperative Pain Management in Appendectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: 60 patients aged 18-65 years undergoing appendectomy were randomised into three groups

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Shahid Mohammadi Hospital, Iran, 60 patients aged 18-65 years undergoing appendectomy

Intervention.evidence: randomised into three groups: dexmedetomidine (n=20), ketorolac (n=20), and control (n=20)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the preemptive/preventive effects of dexmedetomidine versus ketorolac on postoperative pain in appendectomy patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was VAS pain scores at 1, 3, 6, 12, and 24 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, outcome assessors, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 60 patients aged 18-65 years undergoing appendectomy were randomised into three groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: Dexmedetomidine group showed significantly lower VAS scores

Result_Outcome.evidence: Dexmedetomidine group showed significantly lower VAS scores at 12 and 24 hours (1.15 ± 1.98 and 0.95 ± 1.76, P=0.004 and P=0.003) compared to ketorolac and control.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
